Award.AwardTitle: NSF East Asia and Pacific Summer Institute for FY 2012 in China
Award.AbstractNarration:
This action funds John Villavert of the University of Colorado at Boulder to conduct a research project, entitled "Mathematical examination of properties of solutions to important models in science and engineering," during the summer of 2012 at Shanghai Jiao Tong University in Shanghai, China. The host scientist is Lihe Wang.

The Intellectual Merit of the research project is the development of novel mathematical tools that enable a deeper understanding of properties of solutions to physical models - models which are central to many branches of science and engineering. Some examples of such properties include whether the model of differential equations has solutions. If so, how many solutions are there, and do these solutions exhibit the correct physical behavior the model is attempting to capture? Further, the tools developed here may prove valuable in studying more general classes of mathematical models. Moreover, this research has far-reaching impacts not limited only to fundamental theory. For instance, the successful examination of one of the proposed models, important in fluid flow, would allow scientists to numerically compute its solutions - solutions which historically appeared to be nearly impossible to obtain and required vast computational resources. Tools developed in this research can help solve similar difficulties in long-standing open problems from other disciplines.

Broader Impacts of an EAPSI fellowship include providing the Fellow a first-hand research experience outside the U.S.; an introduction to the science, science policy, and scientific infrastructure of the respective location; and an orientation to the society, culture and language. These activities meet the NSF goal to educate for international collaborations early in the career of its scientists, engineers, and educators, thus ensuring a globally aware U.S. scientific workforce.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The main objectives of this research was to establish international collaborations with researchers at Shanghai Jiao Tong University with the purpose of developing mathematical tools which aide in the study of certain classes of non-linear partial differential equations (PDEs)--equations which commonly model numerous yet important physical phenomena. For instance, hyperbolic and elliptic PDEs, which encompass the class of equations studied in this research, can model fluid dynamics, transport of particles, mixing, and heat dissipation just to list a few. Although non-linear equations model many interesting behaviors, studying them can be very difficult. This difficulty stems from the lack of universally applicable tools; that is, studying a particular class of problems requires specific types of tools that may prove ineffective in other cases. Hence, developing such tools in modern mathematics for these non-linear problems is essential to understanding the corresponding physical phenomena.

Once a set of PDEs is derived as a  physical model, one of the most basic questions concerns the well-posedness(existence, uniqueness, and continuous dependence on initial data of solutions) of the problem. If this holds, what qualitative behaviors do the solutions exhibit and what are its ramifications in the physical setting. During the tenure of this fellowship, the PI has developed a method that combines ideas from topological degree theory and classical analysis to prove the existence (and non-existence) of solutions along with their asymptotic behavior for an important class of elliptic systems of the Hardy-Littlewood-Sobolev type. An interesting future direction for this research is on extending the method to tackle other relevant dynamic problems. Another aspect of this research developed regularization methods for hyperbolic conservation laws. This regularization technique aims to modify the models so that the resulting new model is easier to study. For instance, the governing equations of inviscid flows are extremely difficult to numerically simulate. Regularization methods can be implemented to examine a nicer model in the sense that it is more efficient and cost-effective to solve numerically, however, the nicer model still retains the physical features of the original. Nevertheless, to be considered a proper regularization technique, a complete theoretical analysis of the technique such as global well-posedness and stability is sought. Under this fellowship, the PI was able to obtain such analytical results for a type of regularization which utilizes a filtering process. The contribution of mathematical tools developed by the PI and its consequences in gaining a better understanding of physical behaviors illustrates the intellectual merit of this research.

The broader impacts of this research includes contributions to other scientific fields. For example, the regularization methods may be useful in solving problems in engineering flows. Perhaps, the difficult problems in computational fluid dynamics may prove tractable by using such methods. Furthermore, the PI generated interesting results along with fruitful discussions with the host researcher and other researchers at the host institute. The EAPSI fellowship inspired the PI to build international connections and to continue future correspondence with the international community at Shanghai Jiao Tong University, even after the fellowship period. This clearly achieves one of the primary goals of the EAPSI program of fostering and encouraging relationships between US researchers and their international counterparts.
